DOC.UNK: Hungry Zoo Invaders Mistake Rare Bird for Turkey
DOC.TEXT: When Ermelindo Martins saw what looked like a giant turkey loose in Rio's zoo, visions of a Christmas feast overcame his good sense. In a pre-dawn raid Tuesday, Martins and a friend attracted the long-necked bird to the fence and broke its neck. As they prepared to load the 65-pound carcass into a supermarket cart, they were caught by the night watchman and taken to a police station. There they learned that their victim was a rhea, a rare, ostrich-like bird from Brazil's central plains. Killing one is considered an ``ecological crime'' and punishable by up to six years in prison. ``It doesn't look anything like a turkey. And its meat is hard, almost inedible,'' said zoo spokeswoman Esther Nazareth. She explained that the zoo had five _ now four _ rheas that were allowed to roam the grounds at night. They had not been molested until now, she said. Martins, 22, and his 16-year-old companion, whom police did not identify because he is a minor, said at the 17th precinct station that they lived in the Tuiuti Hill shantytown and had simply been looking for dinner. ``We're not criminals, we were just hungry. We thought we were seeing a turkey _ big, but a turkey,'' Martins told the Rio newspaper O Globo.
